description.value:
Rite of the Cardboard Palace
Mystic Rite • Level 2

Time: 30 minutes
Cost: 3 Gnosis
Requirement: A mundane structure or collection of materials capable of forming shelter

Description

The Rite of the Cardboard Palace calls upon spirits of shelter, survival, and humility to elevate a humble space into a place of temporary safety and dignity. What would otherwise be ignored — cardboard, scrap wood, abandoned buildings — becomes sufficient for rest and refuge.

This Rite does not create luxury. It ensures no Garou is left without shelter.

Effect

When the Gnosis cost is paid, the Rite succeeds automatically.

Choose a non-magical structure or assemblage of materials capable of providing cover (such as a shack, alley shelter, abandoned building, or improvised dwelling). For the next 24 hours, the space gains the following benefits:

  • The shelter becomes structurally sound, resisting collapse from normal weather and wear
  • The interior remains dry, insulated, and habitable, regardless of external conditions
  • Creatures resting within the shelter gain the normal benefits of a long rest, even in otherwise hostile environments

This Rite does not prevent intrusion, violence, or detection.

Mechanical Clarifications

The Rite:

  • Does not create a structure from nothing
  • Does not grant defensive bonuses
  • Does not conceal occupants from detection
  • The shelter remains mundane in appearance
  • Environmental hazards beyond normal exposure (lava, floods, siege weapons) still affect the shelter normally

Limitations

This Rite cannot be used on:

  • Structures already fortified or magically enhanced
  • Locations actively collapsing or being destroyed

A given shelter may only be affected by this Rite once per Caern Turn. The effects end immediately if the structure is destroyed.

Narrative Use

The Rite of the Cardboard Palace is commonly used to:

  • Shelter kinfolk or displaced Garou
  • Establish temporary safe havens
  • Survive hostile urban or wilderness conditions without drawing attention

It is a Rite of endurance, not comfort.
